description: From Middle English phisik, from Latin physicus, from Ancient Greek φῠσῐκός (phusikós, “natural; physical”), from φύσις (phúsis, “origin, birth; nature, quality; form, shape; type, kind”), from φῠ́ω (phúō, “grow”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bʰuH- (“to appear, become, rise up”).

adjectives.description: physic (comparative more physic, superlative most physic)

entries.meaning: Relating to or concerning existent materials; physical.

description: From Middle English fysike (noun) and phisiken, fisike (verb; from the noun), from Old French fisike (“natural science, art of healing”), from Latin physica (“study of nature”), from Ancient Greek φυσική (phusikḗ), feminine singular of φῠσῐκός (phusikós, “natural; physical”), see above.

entries.meaning: (archaic, countable) A medicine or drug, especially a cathartic or purgative.
(archaic, uncountable) The art or profession of healing disease; medicine.
examples: ...and thus draw out all the unwholesome Air and Stench, which does more harm than any Physick can repair.

verbs.description: physic (third-person singular simple present physics, present participle physicking, simple past and past participle physicked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To administer medicine to, especially a purgative.
